Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Remote Therapeutic Patient Engagement and Communication System
Award.AbstractNarration:
More than 40 million Americans suffer from anxiety. This creates a major social and economic burden upon individuals, their families and employers. One proven treatment for anxiety recovery is cognitive-behavioral psychotherapy. Treatment involves in-clinic psycho-education and out-of-clinic homework for the patient to complete at home or in their daily lives. While cognitive behavior therapies have been proven to help anxiety disorders, positive outcomes depend on patient engagement with their homework for a prolonged period of time. Unfortunately, the paper- or workbook-based homework often has the following problems: (1) clients try to hide their homework from family and friends who care; (2) they often intentionally or unintentionally forget to do homework; (3) while the clinicians expect the client to do homework off-session, the client hopes to do it as much in-session as possible for the reasons mentioned above. Thus, the clinician can be frustrated when the client fails to do homework as expected, and clients can be frustrated when they don?t see the promised improvement. This project seeks to quantify the potential commercial market for a mobile health platform designed to support clinicians providing cognitive behavioral therapy and their patients.

The proposed technology will engage patients with digital cognitive behavior change exercises through a secure HIPAA compliant platform. In addition, other functions related to therapy, such as recording in-the-moment anxious episodes, will be done through an easy and intuitive mechanism using our technology rather than recording on sheets of paper or recollecting from memory later on. Clinicians will also have secure access to review patient's progress as well as to set-up engagement reminders. The proposed innovation provides a secure and engaging environment for clients that supplement their treatment with the clinician. In addition to typical clinicians and patients, this team will explore the potentials for organizations such as universities to sponsor their at-risk students and employees to use our system as a mobile health tool for promoting wellbeing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our research team developed a mobile application to help aid treatment and communication for patients suffering from anxiety disorder. We adopted a gamified approach to deliver our treatment sessions in the hope to increase patient engagement with our mobile app. In addition, our app allowed patients to self-journal their mood swings and capture in-the-moment of their negative thoughts. Participation in the I-Corps program allowed our team to examine the value of our mobile application from a real-world prospective as well as assess potential sustainability mechanism for the software development and maintenance.

Over 7 weeks of interview during I-Corps program, our team interviewed 98 stakeholders in the healthcare field. This included insurance companies, hospitals, individual clinics, clinicians, patients suffering from anxiety disorder, family members who have beloved ones suffering from mental disorder. The responses we've received from these interviews gave us 3 strong signals: 1. healthcare is a really complex ecosystem with many different stakeholders, 2. innovation in healthcare is appreciated but is slow to implement, 3. there could be more innovative ways to deliver therapy, in our case, behavioral therapy. Our team also gained invaluable knowledge and feedback on the financial, marketing and regulatory issues from I-Corps mentors that are experienced in the healthcare field.

The outcome of the I-Corps program was a pivot from our original idea of delivering behavioral therapy through mobile application into creating a platform for therapy delivery. This change of direction was a direct confirmation from our customers (patients and family members) whom didn't really care about a mobile app for treatment. We've heard from patterns of strong needs and wants specifically from the autism community, where autistic children also suffer from anxiety disorders due to common co-morbidity within mental disorders. They wanted an innovative therapy delivery platform to allow their children to benefit and progress from different behavioral therapy. We further used the remaining I-Corps funding to build a pilot platform to test our ideas with autistic children and their parents. The idea was well received from the families that participated in the pilot program. We are currently assessing additional needed resources to further scale this program and possible venture. The NSF I-Corps program had helped our research team significantly not only to understand if our research findings had a need and want but also humbled us to ask better research questions that could create far bigger impact to our community.
